qas.question: What maintains a historical understanding of jewish Identity?
What does orthodoxy reject as a means of establishing Jewish identiy?
What is intermarriage typically seen as?
What happens to most intermarried people in the orthodox community?
Who maintains the modern understanding of Jewish identity?
What is a person who is born to a Jewish father considered?
What descent by the father does Orthodoxy accept?
What form of marriage is an acceptance of Judaism?
What does the Orthodox Community avoid doing to intermarried couples?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Orthodox Judaism<b5_0/><a0_0/> maintains the historical understanding of Jewish identity. A <b6_0>Jew<b6_0/> is someone who was born to a Jewish mother, or who converts to Judaism in accordance with Jewish law and tradition. Orthodoxy thus rejects <a1_0><b7_0>patrilineal<b7_0/> descent<a1_0/> as a means of establishing Jewish identity. Similarly, Orthodoxy strongly condemns <a2_0>intermarriage<a2_0/>. <b8_0>Intermarriage<b8_0/> is seen as a deliberate <a3_0>rejection of Judaism<a3_0/>, and an intermarried person is effectively <a4_0><b9_0>cut off<b9_0/><a4_0/> from most of the Orthodox community. However, some Orthodox Jewish organizations do reach out to intermarried Jews.
